Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Program in Multi-scale Biological Networks
Award.AbstractNarration: A Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Sites award has been made to Rice University that will provide research training for 10 students, for 10 weeks during the summers of 2013-2015. The program focuses on biological networks, complex interactions among biomolecules that give rise to the diverse biological phenotypes observed in nature. Students will work on research projects under faculty mentors that draw from a range of approaches (classical biochemical and genetic to non-trivial theoretical models that require computation) to study naturally-occurring genetic networks, artificial genetic and metabolic networks, and biomolecular structure, function, and evolution. Faculty with biological interests in diverse departments will serve as mentors, including professors within the Departments of Biochemistry & Cell Biology, Bioengineering, Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering, Chemistry, Computer Science, and Ecology & Evolutionary Biology. Students are expected to do full-time lab research as well as participate in seminars and workshops that focus on responsible conduct in research, professional communication skills, career opportunities, and the graduate school application process. Students are also provided a creative opportunity to develop innovative biotechnological ideas and a capstone research poster symposium. Students will be recruited nationwide, with particular emphasis on students enrolled at proximal minority-serving two- and four-year institutions. Selection of students will be done based on the faculty steering committee?s evaluation of each applicant?s transcript and recommendation letters. Rice?s Institute of Biosciences and Bioengineering (IBB) administers this NSF REU Program and maintains a database of all the alumni for this program with tracking information on their career progression. Assessment of this program is done via pre- and post-questionnaires as well by using the common assessment tool available to BIO-funded REU PIs. Each year, IBB publishes a ?Class Notes? newsletter of the NSF REU alumni and features news on their current academic or professional status and accomplishments. More information is available by visiting the IBB website (http://ibb.rice.edu/Content.aspx?id=563) or by contacting the PI (Dr. George Bennett at gbennett@rice.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Joff Silberg at joff@rice.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are multiple challenges associated with improved training of the future generation of biological researchers in the tools that will be critical to solving problems in this field. Current strategies that simply focus on modifying undergraduate curriculum have been limited in the pace at which they achieve their goals. With this approach, students often do not choose the more quantitative tracks that become available within their biological major because their excitement was not stimulated before they declared that major. In addition, students that pursue such tracks often do not obtain enough depth in quantitative concepts to serve them well in their future careers. To overcome this challenge, a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Sites was coordinated at Rice University that provided research training for 10 students per summer, for 10 weeks during the summers of 2013-2015. This approach was used to provide students earlier exposure to the importance of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics in biological research. 

Students were recruited nationwide, with particular emphasis on students enrolled at proximal minority-serving two- and four-year institutions. Extensive efforts were made to recruit from two-year community college institutions, including proximal institutions such as Houston Community College and San Jacinto College, which have large enrollments (>100,000 students). These resulted in a dramatic (10-fold) increase in applicants from these institutions from 2013-2015. Selection of students was done based on the faculty steering committee’s evaluation of each applicant’s transcript and recommendation letters Rice’s Institute of Biosciences and Bioengineering (IBB) administered this NSF REU Program and supported this program. Efforts were made to recruit from diverse group. During the period of this award, more than half of the interns were from underrepresented groups, more than half of the interns were women, and more than half of the interns were enrolled at schools that lack research opportunities such as two-year institutions.

This topical focus of this program was biological networks, complex interactions among biomolecules that give rise to the diverse biological phenotypes observed in nature. Students worked on research projects under faculty mentors that drew from a range of approaches (classical biochemical and genetic to non-trivial theoretical models that require computation) to study naturally-occurring genetic networks, artificial genetic and metabolic networks, and biomolecular structure, function, and evolution. Faculty from diverse departments served as mentors, including faculty within the Departments of Biochemistry & Cell Biology, Bioengineering, Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering, Chemistry, Computer Science, and Ecology & Evolutionary Biology. Students were matched with faulty mentors who pursued similar undergraduate majors, which catalyzed discussions of the ways in which diverse majors can support cutting-edge biological research. 

In this program, students conducted full-time lab research and participated in seminars and workshops with topics ranging from responsible conduct in research and professional communication skills to career opportunities and the graduate school application process. Additional activities included attendance of faculty presentations on bionetworks research, a tour of a Texas Medical Center research facility, and cohort building activities. Students were also provided a creative opportunity to develop innovative technological ideas in small groups, as well as a capstone research poster symposium. The group projects within this REU site provided a unique creative outlet for students, which they typically do not experience in standard research projects. By having the students work in small multidisciplinary groups, we fostered student-student interactions across disciplines and exposed students to the benefits and challenges required by today’s team approach to STEM projects.
